Title: Evaluation of the National Tutoring Programme (NTP) Year 3 Proj_7118 con_17347
Description:
This project involves an independent evaluation of the National Tutoring Programme in year 3 and includes

Process and Implementation Evaluation
Two surveys and a series of interviews, focus groups and case studies with schools, pupils, delivery partners and tuition partners

Impact Evaluation
Quasi experimental methodology with an intervention and comparison group using administrative data collected in the census about tutoring received and SATs and GCSE results in English and Maths 

Outputs
There will be one interim report covering Year 6 analysis, we will ask the supplier to deliver this in December 2023. 
There will then be a final impact report covering Year 6 and Year 11 analysis, with a draft of this report being delivered in March 2024 and a finalised report by end of April 2024.

Organisation Name: Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens Kew
Title: RBGKEW1084 - Venue Hire & Commercial Filming Security Services
Description:
Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew is looking for a supplier to provide security services at the majority of its Venue Hire Events and Commercial Media Shoots.

The majority of the events broadly fall into the extended 'wedding season' of April to October, during which time there are frequently multiple events taking place on the same day. Events often take place on Friday, Saturdays and Sundays, but can occur any day of the week including Bank Holidays.
Along with Kew's Venue Hire events there is also the opportunity to provide services for our Foundation Events department. They require Event security staff to support with a variety of member and donor events including official visits to the Gardens they host across the year. These services will be required on an ad hoc basis and are not always hosted within our venue portfolio.

To apply follow these steps
- Go to https://defra.bravosolution.co.uk/web/login.html
- Click on 'view Current Opportunities'
- Scroll the list to locate 'RBGKEW1084 - Venue Hire & Commercial Filming Security Services'
- Click on the title
- Follow the instructions to register and obtain the tender documents

Title: Healthcare Market Landscape Study Bahrain - Awarded
Description: Bahrain's Economic Development Board, a government investment promotion agency, has approached the British Embassy (BE) in Bahrain to support them in undertaking a healthcare market study to expand the existing value proposition in the healthcare sector. This will assess current public and private provision through a report to identify market gaps, future demand, patient and sector requirements, the need for specialist facilities. The report will also provide recommendations for new hospital projects including size, specialisms, geographic suitability, segmentation, patient demographics, regional demand, suitability for international partnerships, required investment and potential costs. This study should also include a financial modelling sub-section related to UK companies, as a way of facilitating future value propositions. The Implementer will conduct a study visit to Bahrain for up to 2 weeks, followed by extensive research to produce a market study report that provides an evaluation of the current private healthcare provision, market gaps, and new areas for the development of new hospitals, as well as an assessment and recommendations on healthcare growth requirements e.g. to boost healthcare tourism, provide specialisations, etc.

Title: Provision of Services relating to the Development of a Child Abuse Questionnaire and Safeguarding Procedures - AWARD
Description:
The aim of this research is to design two questionnaires and an appropriate safeguarding procedure. This will be based on topic knowledge, user requirements, cognitive testing with key participant groups, and engagement with topic experts and stakeholders. 
      
      The requirement is defined as two questionnaires as it is essential prevalence estimates are produced for children aged 11 to 17 years and adults aged 18 to 25 years. However, we recognise there may be variations in the questionnaire across ages within these groups, such as the questions and survey text. Alongside this, an appropriate safeguarding procedure should be designed which successfully contributes to ensuring the participants are safe from others who may put them at significant risk of harm. 
      
      ONS will be establishing a steering group to ensure stakeholders and key topic experts are consulted in the design and approach. The terms of reference for the group will be designed by ONS and the chair and secretariat (for example, hosting and minute taking) will also be provided by ONS. It is desirable that the supplier will be able to help recruit for the group based on their connections with experts in the field and collaborate with ONS in using this group to ensure a successful outcome for the project. Potential suppliers are encouraged to set out their ability to do so in their bid. 
      
      The research has been split into two parts, A, and B. Although they focus on different aspects, the two parts of research are not independent of each other as they will need to be approached simultaneously to ensure the survey questions provide information needed for appropriate safeguarding to be administered. 
      
      For part A, two final questionnaires should be provided that have undergone cognitive testing with key participant groups. The final deliverable includes a report detailing the: 
      -text within the survey, such as the introduction to the survey and topics (which may vary by age)  
      -questions (which may vary by age)  
      -question ordering and routing (which may vary by age)  
      -survey length  
      -adaptations to include those with SEND  
      -derivations needed between questions to produce the required prevalence estimates  
      
      For part B, a safeguarding procedure should be provided in relation to part A. The final deliverable includes a report outlining the safeguarding procedure detailing: 
      -any variations in its application across the devolved nations and encompassing regions  
      -any variations in its application across the different modes and ages  
      -the risks associated with the procedures   
      -operational requirements for its implementation  
      
      For both parts (A and B), the final report should also include: 
      -feedback from the engagement with the steering group to provide evidence that the questionnaires and safeguarding procedures are fit for purpose  
      -evidence (including feedback from NSDEC) that the questions and safeguarding proced...
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Edinburgh Innovations|10 Max Born Crescent Murchison House King's Building, Edinburgh, Midlothian, United Kingdom, EH9 3BF|NONE||No|No]

Title: Tech Innovation Framework
Description:
Health and Social Care Information Centre (Known as NHS Digital), on behalf of the Department of Health and Social Care, for the provision of foundation Electronic Patient Record (EPR) solutions and associated capabilities for primary care IT, within a new framework (Tech Innovation Framework, or TIF) and utilising a refreshed set of technology standards and solution capability requirements. The Tech Innovation Framework Lot 1 Framework Agreement will be the contractual vehicle through which Call Off Ordering Parties will purchase Catalogue Solutions from suppliers.
The Tech Innovation Lot 2 Framework Agreement will be the contractual vehicle through which the Contracting Authority or The Health and Social Care Information Centre commission Opportunity Items listed on the Digital Care Services Catalogue Capabilities and Standards Roadmap.

Title: G-Alfea Sonobuoys
Description:
The Royal Navy, part of the UK Ministry of Defence, intends to award a contract to
Ultra Electronics Ltd for the purchase, modification, calibration and testing of 2 off
G-ALFEA sonobuoys. The contract will have a term of 9 months. It is considered that
this contract can be awarded using the negotiated procedure without prior
publication of a contract notice pursuant to Public Contracts Regulations 2015
(Article 32(2)(b)(ii)) for technical reasons. This is because Ultra Electronics Ltd
sonobuoys are required for technical reasons and interoperability, as the existing
systems have been provided by Ultras Electronics Ltd. Ultra Electronics Ltd
represents the UK on the NATO NIAG SG90 Sonobuoy Digital Telemetry panel.
These factors and their understanding of technology arising from the previous R&D
contracts associated with the sonobuoy project within the Underwater Systems
research programme all factor into the technical and interoperability justification.
Ultra Electronics Ltd have also been awarded a contract by DE&S for a through life
sonobuoys contract for RN and RAF. While this is a separate requirement with R&D
elements, interoperability is key and the sonobuoys tested must be Ultra to ensure
technical compatibility in the information gathered in the testing phase with both
the NATO panel and the DE&S sonobuoy contract. Only Ultra Electronics Ltd have
the technical information and knowledge required and no other contractor would
have access to this information.
Contact Address 1: 4 Deck. NCHQ. Leach Building. Whale Island.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Ultra Electronics Limited|418 Bridport Road. Greenford. Middlesex. UB6 8UA|NONE_OTHER||No|No]

Title: LCR Priority Training Support - Holistic Care Programme
Description:
The Skills & Apprenticeship Hub Team are part of the Liverpool City Region Combined Authority and funded by the European Social Fund (ESF) and Strategic Investment Fund (SIF).

The 'Priority Training Support' programme has been developed to support locally based employers from a survey undertook with LCR employers in June 2021.

The programme will operate up to 31 December 2022 and will support LCR employers looking to address specific skills gaps within their existing workforce.

As part of the Priority Training Support Fund, LCRCA wishes to appoint a suitably experienced supplier to deliver a training programme focussed on 'a Holistic Care Programme' to a number of cohorts. These sessions will be fully funded by LCRCA.

Research undertaken by the LCRCA has identified holistic care training as a skills' need for LCR-based employers. As a result of this, LCRCA Skills & Apprenticeship Hub is looking to procure a training provider to satisfy this demand across the City Region.
Additional Text: The tender documents are available on The Chest (www.the-chest.org.uk) under reference DN631855. Tenders must be submitted electronically via the same portal.

Title: Review of storage facilities for  cultural and biocultural heritage material (archaeology) held by Historic England at Fort Cumberland, Portsmouth - AWARD
Description:
Historic England  wishes to develop and improve the storage of its permanent and temporary collections, taking into consideration the variety of types of collection we hold, the historic nature of the buildings and sustainability. 
      
      Due to aging infrastructure, changing business needs and collection development, the current environmental systems and stores are unable to achieve consistent appropriate temperature and humidity conditions for the different materials held.
      
      Historic England wish to engage a museum collections care and storage consultant to: 
      
      1. Undertake a root and branch review of how the Fort Cumberland archives and collections are currently stored, their requirements and how the building performances and current environmental controls affect the stored materials.
      2. Put together sustainable options for adapting and building new innovative collection curation facilities, within Grade II and II* Listed Buildings,which are fit for purpose and will meet our current needs and future ambitions to improve accessibility for professional and public engagement.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [National Conservation Service (Conservation Ltd)|NCS 21 Albemarle Street, Mayfair, London, United Kingdom, W1S 4BS|NONE||No|No]

Title: Employment & Skills Lincolnshire PR, Marketing and Design Services
Description:
Lincolnshire County Council wishes to procure a Supplier to lead the delivery of a customised programme of PR and marketing activities utilising a range of digital and traditional solutions aimed at raising awareness of employment and skills services within the Lincolnshire County Council area with a view to increasing take up of provision.

The Council are looking for a supplier to develop, manage and deliver a Communication Plan to support awareness raising of Employment and Skills and associated Council services in Lincolnshire.

Quotations are invited in respect of PR and marketing services to support and promote Employment and Skills Lincolnshire activities.  The successful supplier will be responsible for providing this service, liaising closely with the Principal Officer for Learning and Skills.

Through this contract the Council wish to deliver a clear, targeted and intelligence led communication plan which delivers clear messages to all interested parties. In order to ensure that communications are effective, the Supplier should initiate research in order to develop a 'Communications Intelligence Report' which considers the various audience groups and defines how best to communicate with these groups, considering the best communication channels, message format and frequency of delivery.             
  
Full details of the requirement are available in the RFQ, which can be downloaded using the link below:
https://procontract.due-north.com/Advert?advertId=c9e45e44-9844-ed11-811a-005056b64545&fromProjectDashboard=True

Organisation Name: NHS South, Central and West Commissioning Support Unit
Title: WA13126 - HNA for L&D Services & hosted Reconnect Services across the South West
Description:
NHS England Health & Justice South West are seeking a suitable provider to carry out Health Needs Assessments (HNAs) for the commissioning of Health provision into five Liaison and Diversion services and hosted Reconnect Services. It is also expected that the provider will produce  a consolidated regional report.    

The requirement is for five full Liaison and Diversion Health Needs Assessments for the following services:
•	Avon & Somerset Liaison and Diversion Service, to include Reconnect services at HMP Bristol and HMP Eastwood Park
•	Devon & Cornwall Liaison and Diversion Service, to include Reconnect services at HMP Channings Wood and HMP Exeter
•	Dorset Liaison and Diversion Service
•	Gloucestershire Liaison and Diversion Service
•	Wiltshire Liaison and Diversion Service


The purpose of the Health Needs Assessments are:

•	To facilitate the understanding of health needs/vulnerabilities of service users of the five South West Liaison and Diversion Services and the hosted Reconnect Services (for the areas applicable))
•	To identify current service delivery models and gaps in service provision and make clear recommendations for commissioners 
•	Make distinction between adults and young people
•	Identity and make clear distinction to additional hosted services 
•	To support commissioners to prioritise resources 
•	To assist decision makers in the maintaining, planning and future improvement of services which address need, efficiency and effectiveness
•	To identify the changing demographics of the local population
•	To identify equity and inequity duties of NHS England 

The purpose of the Consolidated Regional report is:

•	To summarise key findings, recommendations and themes from all five HNAs and to incorporate reviews/findings (already undertaken), of South West criminal justice services that fall outside of L&D and Reconnect, specifically, Court Healthcare and MHTRs 
•	To facilitate a better understanding of the need and likely demand for integrated Non-custodial services
•	To support commissioners to prioritise resources 
•	To assist decision makers in the maintaining, planning and future improvement of services which address need, efficiency and effectiveness

A single contract will be let to deliver the above requirements, with a maximum total contract value of £129,000.

The HNAs will be undertaken over a period of 20 weeks with the aim to commence in December (2022). 

This procurement is being carried out by NHS South, Central and West Commissioning Support Unit (SCW) on behalf of the Commissioners.

Title: CEFAS222-45 Bespoke Marine Circulation System
Description:
Cefas require a bespoke Marine Recirculation System for housing and breeding marine invertebrate species. The new system will allow to expand number of species for ecotoxicology testing and capacity for maintaining longer term cultures required for regulatory and R&D work. 

The system design should contain a bespoke filter with a capacity of static sump volume between 300-500 litres and a variable sump volume between 100-200 litres. The pump should run at quite low speed and be quiet in operation. It is proposed to utilise the existing wet benches to accommodate a number of tanks. The treatment plant shall also have mechanical filtration, bio-filtration and UV treatment to ensure good water quality for the resident livestock. 
The system will be designed to be flexible so the tanks can be easily arranged or exchanged. Also, future capacity upgrade should be considered

Organisation Name: Department of Health and Social Care (London)
Title: National HIV/Syphilis self-sampling and self-testing Framework
Description:
This is a National Framework Agreement with a single contractor to provide HIV sand Syphilis self-sampling and self-testing and results management services. The framework will be primarily for use by the Department of Health and Social Care, the lead Authority, but it will be opened for use by:
• any local authority in England; A-Z of councils online | Local Government Association
• NHS England and NHS Improvement; NHS England » Contact us
• any Integrated Care Board, NHS Trust or NHS Foundation Trust in England (NHS England » NHS provider directory)

The aim of this service is to provide a cost effective and clinically robust service accessible for sexually active individuals aged 16 years and over. Emphasis will be placed on increasing testing for HIV amongst most at risk groups including gay and bisexual men and other men who have sex with men and black African populations. The service will be paid for by the customer and will be free to the service user.
The service provision includes four elements:
• User interface and access (online portal)
• Fulfilment of orders (online and offline distribution)
• Pathology
• Results management

Contract term: 24 months with the option to extend for up to further 24 months
Contract value (including extensions): £3,900,000 excluding VAT (£4,600,000 including VAT)

Title: Professional Development Programme - Phase 3
Description:
This contract will deliver the third phase of the Early Years Professional Development Programme (PDP3). PDP3 will build on two earlier phases of the programme (PDP1 and PDP2).
The objective of PDP3, a Continuing Professional Development (CPD) programme, is to equip up to 10,000 Early Years Practitioners (EYPs) with the skills they need to provide high quality support for early years children (age 2 - 4) by March 2025. This programme will have a particular emphasis on communication and language, maths, and Personal, Social and Emotional Development (PSED). The Contract covers all upper tier Local Authorities (across England), with a focus on reaching Settings with high levels of disadvantaged children whose learning has been most affected by COVID-19.

Derbyshire County Council are seeking a provider with a successful background in business-to-business marketing to lead on Phases 4, 5 and 6 over a two-year period. To  •	develop a marketing strategy, a marketing and communication plan, marketing materials and a launch plan. 
•	Support in the implementation and delivery of the marketing and communications plan.
•	A review of the impact of the marketing and communications plan and materials and make necessary amendments to them on a 6 monthly basis to ensure the marketing and materials remains relevant.
The contract is due to commence on 01 November 2022 for a two year period.

Description:
This tender is to procure computer systems that provide functional requirements to support the activities undertaken by the Environment, Transport & Infrastructure (ETI) Directorate. Many of these functions the system will be used for are statutory requirements for this service.   
      
        
      
      It has been identified that it is necessary to replace the current system we use provided by WSP, WSP Works Management System (hereafter called WSP WMS). Procurement of this new system will deliver all necessary functionalities to replace the outgoing WSP WMS system from April 27th 2023 and will ensure adequate scalability and futureproofing to adapt to future changes to H&T & ETI requirements. The timeline of this project will ensure that the solutions being procured are tested and aligned in time for the start of second year of contract with Ringway (Highways Maintenance contract).  
      
       
      
      The scope of this project is broader than just to replace the functionality provided by WSP WMS and includes functionality currently provided by other systems that would be brought under one system where possible. It requires the procured system meet functional requirements under following headings: 
      
       
      
      Customer Services  
      
      Asset Management  
      
      Works Management 
      
      Defect Management  
      
      Mobile Working  
      
      Routine Maintenance  
      
      Street Works  
      
      Claims & Payments  
      
      Reporting & Data  
      
      Integrations

Title: An Evaluation of the UK global screen fund pilot - AWARD
Description:
The UK market for feature film and high-end television has been on an upward trajectory in recent years.
      On top of the economic benefits the UK screen sector is considered one of the most established and influential cinema and television content-makers in the world. Beyond cultural impact, the quality of British filmmaking, TV production and animation and narrative games are globally recognised, UK audio-visual schools are highly regarded worldwide, and the nationally produced visual effect industry often leads the way in innovation. 
      
      Despite this, the independent screen sector faces a number of challenges, as identified by the BFI's recent Economic Review of UK Independent Film . In this report, the UK Global Screen Fund was identified as one of the existing interventions designed to address the downward trend in independent film activity and support the sector to find new markets for UK content.
      The UK Global Screen Fund (UKGSF) was established as a 1-year pilot fund in 2021-22
      
      We would like to commission an evaluation of the pilot year of the UKGSF. The evaluation should assess the impacts of the UKGSF in its first year of operation, and also the processes around its implementation. 
      We expect the evaluation in the pilot year of the UKGSF to cover three distinct elements  process evaluation, impact evaluation and  economic evaluation.

Procurement for the Sheffield Mental Health Guide Service. The Sheffield Mental Health Guide plays a significant role in Mental Health Commissioning's forward business plan. Given the scale of mental health difficulties faced by Sheffield people, it is essential that we find accessible and innovative ways to inform and advise people about how to respond when problems arise.
The Sheffield Mental Health Guide is part of the city's response to provide tailored and specific information around this area. The site contributes to key health and wellbeing aims. Title: Online Educational Cancer Resource primarily for Primary Care
Description:
GatewayC has been funded to date by a combination of revenue streams, including the NHS Vanguard Programme, Health Education England, Cancer Research UK, Cancer Alliance investment, and The Christie NHS Foundation Trust. Funding for the core programme of activity is secured until July 2022. After this, without further support, GatewayC's core activities will be unsustainable, and regional developments, which have been extensions of GatewayC, will also be untenable.

This proposal is for 2022-23 for sustained funding for the core aspects of GatewayC primary care cancer education portal, developed with funding from Health Education England.
This proposal covers:
• Continuation and ongoing development of the core aspects of GatewayC including
o The online courses
o National webinars,
o Cancer Conversations
o Cancer Keys
• Continue piloting migration of GatewayC onto the e-Learning for Healthcare platform
• Development of additional 5 modules of online learning

Title: Faraday Battery Challenge (Phase 2) - Evaluation
Description:
*** THIS IS AN AWARD NOTICE, NOT A CALL FOR COMPETITION ***

This procurement is being concluded following a mini competition under the CCS Framework Research & Insights DPS RM6126

Brief Description of Requirement
Background

The UK Research & Innovation (UKRI) Board are committed to collecting evidence to understand the impacts of the Faraday Battery Challenge. Bidders are invited to bid for an evaluation of the Programme to gain insight into the outcomes and impact of phase two of the programme. An independent evaluation of phase one is currently underway.

Aims and Objectives of the Project

UKRI is seeking to commission an independent impact evaluation of the Faraday Battery Challenge Phase 2 with the aim to understand the extent to which FBC2 is continuing to make an impact, taking into account its original goals and building on the work undertaken during Phase 1. The evaluation needs to test the extent to which the programme will deliver the outcomes and impact as expected and outlined in the delivery plan and the extent to which these are attributable to programme funding. As well as interim outcomes, appointed evaluators should have a key role in defining evaluation scope and identifying impacts that can be realised within the Challenge Lifecyle. It is expected that the evaluation will consider each strand of the programme in detail, as well as the overall impact of the combined programme.

Title: Third party broker to remunerate patient engagement & care
Description:
In order to support the Personalised Care and Maternity programmes within the region, a provider (peer led or relevant to personalised care) is sought to support, and remunerate Peer Leaders and Maternity Service User Voice representatives in the involvement, co-creation and co-production of activities aligned with the personalised care and maternity workstreams. Being able to support a group of people who are confident and able to take part in this benefits a range of organisations and enables the voice and perspective of people with lived experience to be maximised.

The London Personalised Care team has recruited and created a Regional Strategic Co-production Group made up of people with lived experience of personalised care who are confident and willing to engage in the programme at a strategic level. The details of these people will be made available to the successful provider (subject to consent from the group members).

The London Personalised Care team has recently set up working groups to support with delivering change across the region for personalised care. These groups are made up of people with lived experience to support the group to coproduce personalised care

The Maternity regional team and Clinical Network draws on the network of Maternity Voices Partnerships and other service users to ensure that the service user voice is central to a number of projects across the region.

      The 'Opt Out' functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision.

Description:
Stratford School Academy is a co-educational Secondary School in Forest Gate, London. It has two campuses at Upton Lane and Grosvenor Road and over 1500 students between the ages of 11 and 16 on roll and 136 teaching and support staff. The Academy is successful and growing; as a result of this success the Academy is planning to build a SEN extension to the Grosvenor Road Campus with an expected project commencement start date of November 2022 and the extension is expected to be opened by September 2023.

Title: Occupational Therapy Services in the London Borough of Newham
Description:
Newham Council has commissioned the Occupational Therapy Services in the London Borough of Newham since November 2018. The Care Act 2014 states that Occupational Therapists (OT's) are well placed to undertake assessment or review of an individual or carer with standard or complex support needs.

Occupational Therapy intervention is primarily preventative and the cost benefits associated with the provision of personalised home adaptations is well evidenced. OT's are effective at preventing, reducing or delaying the need for care and support based on a holistic picture of the individual or family, taking into consideration informal support networks and an asset-based approach which is complementary to maximising individual and community Resilience.

The overall outcome for Adult Services is to promote the wellbeing of people in Newham, making the best use of available resources to enable adults to live in the community independently and safely, free from abuse and neglect.

The Council has not been able to award the proposed Contract.

Title: Investigation into Unauthorised Structural Subsystems
Description:
NOT AWARDED - no bids received - tender published again as ORR/CT/22-38 

The ORR are aware of an issue where sub-systems have been brought into use without an Interoperability authorisation. The ORR want, on a NR Region basis the following;
1. The size of the issue determined (i.e the number of sub-systems brought into use without an authorisation where an authorisation was most likely required).
2. The significance of the issue in terms of regulatory compliance as well as future safety, quality and cost implications. 
3. An evidenced opinion on the cause(s) of the issue.
4. An informed opinion on whether the issue is ongoing and whether NR are adequately addressing the issue.
The scope shall include the following:
•	NR led and 3rd Party projects going back to 1st April 2017.Collecting evidence from Network Rail Sponsors, DEAM's and Capital Delivery Directors on current and previous construction projects dating back to 2017 with ORR authorisation tracker
•	Investigating a sample of infrastructure project completed, including but not exclusively 3rd party station projects dating back up to 5 years, use this a base line, collect statements from Network Rail
•	Investigating a sample of current projects in progress but not captured in ORR authorisation tracker 
•	The consultant shall ensure the Network Rail and 3rd party owned projects receive equal scrutiny, we are interested to understand the relationship that both 3rd parties and Network Rail have with the authorisation process
•	Understanding relationship of ASPRO (Asset Protection and Optimisation) with 3rd parties
•	Understanding why any identified unauthorised works continued without a Network Change Notification 
•	Investigating differences in process and acceptance between SRPs (System Review panel) across the regions to understand level of variability across the Network 
•	Provide evidence of good and poor practices
Attachments: Bravosolution Joining Instruction for open tender.doc ORR CT 22-17 Form of Tender - Fixed Fee.doc ORR CT 22-17 Disclaimer.doc ORR CT 22-17 ITT - Unauthorised Structural Subsystems.docx ORR CT 22-17 Draft Form of Agreement.docx

Title: Decarbonisation Pilots: Heat Decarbonisation Plans Contract Award - ECS
Description:
Contract Award for the following requirement:

The DfE requires Heat Decarbonisation Plans to be produced for 200 Schools which must follow the guidance set by Salix (the Administrator working on behalf of BEIS). The HDPs need to be completed by the end of February 2022.


Description of Specialist Professional Services / deliverables required:

The purpose of a HDP is to describe how an organisation intends to replace fossil fuel reliant systems with low carbon alternatives (e.g. Heat Pumps).
A HDP describes the current state of an organisation's energy use and its plans for reducing and/or decarbonising its energy use. The plan outlines what an organisation has already done, what it is currently doing, what it plans to do in the future. The plan explains what actions are going to be taken, over what timescales, and the intended outcomes.

Title: South Cliff Health and Wellbeing Scoping
Description:
2.1.1	South Cliff Caravan Park is the most valuable asset the Council holds in terms of net income generation.  The 2018/19 financial outturn provided a surplus of £1.925m. This has shown a steady increase year on year and continues to do so. It is anticipated that the net surplus for 2020/2021 financial year will be £3.225m.
The park currently comprises the following: 
•	862 permanent static caravan pitches 
•	208 touring pitches 
•	51 tent pitches 
•	40 fleet hire caravans and lodges for holiday lettings 
•	Two shower blocks, reception and Facility Manager's office 
•	Four properties with ground leases to third parties - Makis Leisure Centre, South Cliff Takeaway, South Cliff Supermarket and South Cliff Caravan Sales.

The current occupancy levels achieved are: 
Permanent Static Pitches                    	90%
Touring Pitches 	75%
Tenting 	75%
Fleet Hire 	90%





Occupancy levels are high and the site now suffers from limited the opportunities for increasing income further. During popular times of the year some pitches could be sold numerous times.

The site is dissected by a road, Pioneer Road, which runs through the two halves of the park. On the southern side of the park is a newly developed area which houses the majority of our holiday customers and was opened in May 2019. The existing side of the park is caravan owner based with no holiday lets on that area.  

2.1.2 	South Cliff also operates the Bridlington Park and Ride scheme which is situated on Wilsthorpe car park at the top of Pioneer Road, Bridlington, YO15 3QN. This scheme runs from Easter each year through to the end of October, at which point the facility closes for the winter. 

2.2	Requirements 

2.2.1	To consider viable options for high quality commercial opportunities that can make positive revenue contributions and would enhance the Council's Leisure and Tourism offer. 
2.2.2	To explore a health and wellbeing orientated facilities offer to enhance physical activity and / or healthy outcomes. 
2.2.3	To explore the potential of expansion to the current offer (both holiday and ownership) at South Cliff Holiday Park, utilising the land available.
2.2.4	To consult with relevant stakeholders and customers to ascertain their views and opinions as part of the process, at relevant stages. 


2.3	Required Outputs
2.3.1	To fully appraise current service and future delivery options
2.3.2	To engage with relevant stakeholders and customers to inform decisions.
2.3.3	To establish client / stakeholder meetings at regular intervals during the process. 
2.3.4	To propose a draft multi phase project to enable a fully informed decision making process but also to establish current position of the service and provide accurate information on external challenges to the business. 
2.3.5	To present a clear business plan for each phase of the project and present findings to key stakeholders.
